abstract: The blood-testing company, which is under criminal investigation, is replacing its chief operating officer and expanding its board.

abstract: The new venture, the subject of fierce rumors, is aimed at competing with conventional grocery stores, which have taken a bite of Whole Foods’ profits.

abstract: The gift from the former Citigroup chairman and his wife, Joan, will finance a new neuroscience research center.

abstract: Shares of Microsoft and the Google parent Alphabet sank after results fell short of forecasts.

abstract: Shares of American Express sank more than 12 percent after the company said it would slash spending to cope with the rising dollar.

title: How Larry Page’s Obsessions Became Google’s Business
abstract: Mr. Page is hardly the first Silicon Valley chief with a case of intellectual wanderlust, but to a rare degree he has made his company a reflection of his personal fascinations.

title: Amit Singh of Google for Work: A Respectful Clash of Ideas
abstract: The president of Google for Work says it’s important to create a culture where people can present diverse points of view.

title: G.E. Reports Strong Quarterly Profit but Sales Are Below Forecasts
abstract: The industrial conglomerate said lower sales for its oil-field equipment unit hurt revenue, but other units, like jet engines and locomotives, were strong.

title: When Alcohol Intrudes in the Workplace
abstract: A worker is worried about a colleague’s drinking off-site and its effect on performance. In another question, a worker wants to carefully avoid drinking socially.

title: Treasury Secretary Visits Puerto Rico and Urges Fast Action
abstract: Jacob J. Lew said, “Only Congress can enact the legislative measures necessary for Puerto Rico to resolve this problem.”

title: Wealth Inequality Rising Fast, Oxfam Says, Faulting Tax Havens
abstract: Just 62 people own as much wealth as the 3.5 billion people in the bottom half of the world’s income scale, Oxfam reported. Five years ago, it took 388 billionaires to reach that mark.

title: Puerto Rico Revises Plan to Reduce Debt as Optimism Dwindles
abstract: The island’s top economic officials said they had to alter their economic strategy when they saw that tax revenues were running about $500 million lower than forecast.

title: Online Booking Makes Hotel Loyalty Harder to Keep
abstract: The same technology that makes booking a room easy also makes it easier for guests to shop around among hotels based on price or location.

title: Man Dies in France After Painkiller Drug Trial
abstract: French prosecutors have begun a manslaughter investigation after a man died after taking part in an experimental drug trial for a painkiller.

title: For Now, Self-Driving Cars Still Need Humans

abstract: The mogul’s purchase of the Plaza Hotel in 1988 offers insight into the methods and thinking of a deal maker turned presidential candidate.

title: Federal Reserve Started 2010 With Hope, Then Fear and Fitful Activism
abstract: Worsening economic conditions in 2010 led the Federal Reserve to act to try to avoid a new recession or a deflationary trap.

title: Kuwait Airways Drops Flights to Avoid Israeli Passengers
abstract: Instead of stopping the practice of blocking Israeli passengers from traveling between New York City and London, as the Transportation Department requested, the airline canceled the flights.

abstract: MGM Resorts International said that it would become the first major casino company to end a longstanding and popular perk: free parking. The move could bring in millions of dollars annually.

title: Hawaiian Airlines and Delta Lead On-Time Rankings
abstract: Hawaiian Airlines and Delta Air Lines again topped the airline on-time rankings for November, released on Friday by the Transportation Department.

abstract: The pact is part of an effort by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to improve safety practices in the auto industry.

title: A Year Junk Bonds Lived Up to Their Name
abstract: Top high-yield bond funds, a.k.a. junk funds, are down as much as 11 percent since summer of 2014, and market volatility points conservative investors toward safer bets.

title: Stock Prices Sink in a Rising Ocean of Oil
abstract: As an oil glut grows despite production cuts, investors worry about a slowdown in the global economy.

title: How Oil Prices Are Falling Again, Explained in Four Charts
abstract: A glut of crude oil on the markets is pushing the price of oil down to levels not seen since the global financial crisis.

title: Investing Advice That Doubles as a Bookmark
abstract: Helaine Olen and Harold Pollack offer financial planning tips you can fit on an index card, and Jane Bryant Quinn writes about having enough money in retirement.

title: For E.T.F. Traders, Lessons From the Panic
abstract: Exchange-traded funds suffered huge losses when stocks plummeted in early trading on Aug. 24, revealing hidden dangers in short-term trading of the funds.

title: Signs of a Retail Rebound as Consumers Take On More Debt
abstract: In moderation, consumer debt can help encourage economic activity, but in excess, it can create bubbles that threaten the economy.

title: Loose Lips Sink Careers, Even for C.E.O.s

title: U.S. Manufacturing and Producer Prices Decline

abstract: The holding company that owns Google is moving the unit from a stand-alone division to a piece of X research and putting a new focus on robots.

abstract: All Chipotle restaurants will open later than usual on Feb. 8 so employees can discuss safety changes, the chain said.

abstract: Strategists say investors may be focusing too much on the role energy has played in recent declines, even as they underestimate other risks.

abstract: The giant retailer said about 16,000 employees would be affected by the move.

abstract: The Chinese appliances company snapped up G.E. Appliances after a deal with Electrolux of Sweden fell apart last year.

abstract: After long holding off on a big overhaul, Morgan Stanley is cutting hundreds of jobs on its troubled bond and commodity trading desks.

abstract: The founder of Sprinklr says he has found a naïve belief in people can bring out the best in them.

abstract: For Beijing Kunlun, Grindr offers a chance to expand beyond its gaming assets, as well as markets outside China.

abstract: Jim Rutenberg, chief political correspondent for the Sunday magazine, will fill the role last held by David Carr, who died in February.

abstract: A number of foreign exchange specialists are worried that potential devaluations in South Korea, Singapore and Taiwan could hurt the global economy.

abstract: Malaysia Airlines barred passengers from checking baggage on flights to Paris and Amsterdam Tuesday and Wednesday because of “unseasonably strong headwinds.”

abstract: The blog OnSmash was among music sites shut down in 2010, accused of copyright infringement and selling counterfeit goods.

abstract: China, the world’s second-largest economy, looked set for a weak start to 2016 after activity in the manufacturing sector contracted for a fifth straight month in December.

abstract: The company joins Google, Facebook and others in disclosing when users of email and other services have probably been targeted by hackers working on behalf of governments.

abstract: Turning to some of 2015’s most successful investors and analysts for an annual look at what to expect next year.

abstract: In an interview, Mr. Lucas jokingly compared Disney, which bought the rights to the franchise in 2012, to “white slavers” who had bought his children. He later apologized for the remark.

abstract: Mr. Siminoff replaces Janet Van Huysse, ending a year in which the company was criticized about its minority hiring.

abstract: KaloBios Pharmaceuticals said that two directors had resigned after the arrest of Martin Shkreli, who had been its chief executive, on securities fraud charges this month.

abstract: The latest uproar around Martin Shkreli has nothing to do with drug prices, but allegations of fraud at a small hedge fund.

abstract: The entrepreneur, who has been criticized for price gouging on drugs, faces securities fraud charges related to his work at MSMB Capital Management and Retrophin.

abstract: The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates this week, but waiting until inflation rises would give the Fed more room to respond to a recession.

abstract: Since 2008, the mortgage giants have been held to far more punishing standards than the big banks, opening the door to an attempted Wall Street takeover.

abstract: A hotel cannot examine names of potential guests and reject them based on race, the authors say, but that is common with short-term home rentals.

abstract: The chairwoman of the Federal Reserve has begun the process of raising interest rates, a move that her predecessors have taken in recent decades as they put their own distinctive stamp on the economy.

abstract: Delta Air Lines says it is banning hoverboards — the motorized, two-wheel, skateboard-size scooters — because of the fire danger from the lithium-ion batteries that power the devices.

abstract: With Yahoo’s one billion users and revenue of nearly $5 billion, investors would be salivating if Yahoo were a start-up, not a faded Internet company.

abstract: Moving back and forth between private practice and public service, several people had central roles inside the Obama administration in developing a new housing finance policy that would phase out Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.

abstract: They pop up, they expand, they take over, they even dance: As our screens have shrunk, online advertisements have grown ever more annoying.

abstract: The World Bank, I.M.F. and Asian Development Bank compared.

abstract: Ulrich Hackenberg, a member of the Audi management board responsible for technical development, had been with the Volkswagen group for 30 years.

abstract: Howard Schultz attributes the chain’s recent dazzling performance to the quality of its customers’ experience, and to a newer push toward the high end.

title: Dip in Tourism After Most Attacks Is Short-Lived, Study Says
abstract: An analysis of the impact of terrorist attacks on travel and tourism suggests that the long-term effect is more muted than after a natural disaster.

abstract: As consumer and commercial drones increase in popularity, the government is taking more steps to address safety concerns and regulate the aerial vehicles.

abstract: Chinese money is reshaping real estate markets, as companies and individuals snap up commercial and residential properties.

abstract: The F.D.A. approval clears the way for the first genetically altered animal to enter the American food supply, despite strong opposition.

title: Earnest, Fueled by Growth in Student Loans, Raises $275 Million
abstract: The lender is growing at a torrid pace, lending $2 million to $5 million every day. The start-up says its approach to lending is particularly data-intensive, which it says allows it to tailor rates to individual circumstances.

title: Irmat, a Mail-Order Pharmacy, Sues OptumRx in Latest Drug-Price Skirmish
abstract: The dispute between Irmat and the pharmacy benefit manager OptumRx is part of a recent flurry of attention being paid to the way name-brand pharmaceuticals are marketed.

title: Greece to Receive Another Chunk of Bailout Aid
abstract: European authorities have agreed to disburse $8.4 billion in fresh funds to Greece, allowing the country to keep paying its bills in the coming months.

title: The New Net Neutrality Rules
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission is to take a more active role in regulating the Internet as a public utility, which is expected to provoke court cases from major broadband providers.
